openadk.library.threadpool
Class ThreadPoolManager

java.lang.Object
  openadk.library.threadpool.ThreadPoolManager
All Implemented Interfaces:
MessageDispatchThreadListener
public class ThreadPoolManager
extends java.lang.Object
implements MessageDispatchThreadListener

This class manages a pool of Pull mode threads

To use this class setup as follows.

    // Thread Pooling
    ThreadPoolManager threadPoolManager = new ThreadPoolManager(3);
    threadPoolManager.setThreadRunLimit(300); // 5 minutes

    // Now, connect to all zones to register and query
    for( Zone zone : this.getZoneFactory().getAllZones() ) {
      // Thread Pooling
      zone.setThreadPoolManager(threadPoolManager);

      zone.setSubscriber(schoolInfoHandler, StudentDTD.SCHOOLINFO);
      zone.setQueryResults(schoolInfoHandler);
      try {
         zone.connect(ADKFlags.PROV_REGISTER);
      } catch (Exception e) {
         zone.connect(ADKFlags.PROV_NONE);
      }

      // Request all students
      Query query = new Query(StudentDTD.SCHOOLINFO);
      zone.query(query);
    }

    // Thread Pool start
    threadPoolManager.execute();

Constructor Detail

ThreadPoolManager

public ThreadPoolManager()
Constructor for a thread pool with 1 to 5 threads.

ThreadPoolManager

public ThreadPoolManager(int poolSize)
Constructor for a thread pool with a fixed pool size.

ThreadPoolManager

public ThreadPoolManager(int minPoolSize,
                         int maxPoolSize,
                         long keepAliveTime)
Constructor for a thread pool with a fixed pool size.

Parameters:
minPoolSize - corePoolSize the number of threads to keep in the pool, even if they are idle.
maxPoolSize - the maximum number of threads to allow in the pool.
keepAliveTime - when the number of threads is greater than the core, this is the maximum time in milliseconds that excess idle threads will wait for new tasks before terminating.
Method Detail

shutdown

public void shutdown()
Initiates an orderly shutdown in which previously submitted tasks are executed, but no new tasks will be accepted. Invocation has no additional effect if already shut down.

execute

public void execute()
Call this method to start all tasks that were previously queued through addTask(Runnable) method.

execute

public void execute(java.lang.Runnable task)
Execute task with no initial delay. The task can execute repeatedly with a variable delay if it implements IThreadPoolDelayTask.

Parameters:
task - the task to execute

execute

public void execute(java.lang.Runnable task,
                    long delay)
Execute task after waiting the specified delay. The task can execute repeatedly with a variable delay if it implements IThreadPoolDelayTask.

Parameters:
task - the task to execute
delay - the time in milliseconds to delay before execution

scheduleWithFixedDelay

public java.util.concurrent.ScheduledFuture<?> scheduleWithFixedDelay(java.lang.Runnable task,
                                                                      long initialDelay,
                                                                      long delay)
Creates and executes a periodic task that becomes enabled first after the given initial delay, and subsequently with the given delay between the termination of one execution and the commencement of the next.

Parameters:
task - the task to execute
initialDelay - the time to delay first execution in milliseconds
delay - the delay between the termination of one execution and the commencement of the next in milliseconds
Returns:
a Future representing pending completion of the task, and whose get() method will throw an exception upon cancellation.

getKeepAliveTime

public long getKeepAliveTime()
Returns the thread keep-alive time, which is the amount of time which threads in excess of the core pool size may remain idle before being terminated.

Returns:
the time limit in milliseconds
See Also:
setKeepAliveTime(long)

setCorePoolSize

public void setCorePoolSize(int corePoolSize)
Sets the core number of threads. This overrides any value set in the constructor. If the new value is smaller than the current value, excess existing threads will be terminated when they next become idle. If larger, new threads will, if needed, be started to execute any queued tasks.

Parameters:
corePoolSize - the new core size
See Also:
getCorePoolSize()

setMaximumPoolSize

public void setMaximumPoolSize(int maxPoolSize)
Sets the maximum allowed number of threads. This overrides any value set in the constructor. If the new value is smaller than the current value, excess existing threads will be terminated when they next become idle.

Parameters:
maxPoolSize - the new maximum
See Also:
getMaximumPoolSize()

setKeepAliveTime

public void setKeepAliveTime(long time)
Sets the time limit for which threads may remain idle before being terminated. If there are more than the core number of threads currently in the pool, after waiting this amount of time without processing a task, excess threads will be terminated. This overrides any value set in the constructor.

Parameters:
time - the time to wait in milliseconds. A time value of zero will cause excess threads to terminate immediately after executing tasks.
See Also:
getKeepAliveTime()

removeTask

public boolean removeTask(java.lang.Runnable task)
Removes this task from the executor's internal queue if it is present, thus causing it not to be run if it has not already started.

Parameters:
task - the task to remove
Returns:
true if the task was removed

addTask

public void addTask(java.lang.Runnable task)
Adds a task to be run in a thread pool. Tasks will not start until the execute() method is called. The task can execute with a variable delay if it implements IThreadPoolDelayTask.

Parameters:
task - - Runnable most likely HttpPullProtocolHandler

threadCompleted

public void threadCompleted(java.lang.Runnable r,
                            java.lang.Throwable t)
Called when a task is leaving the active pool and is not scheduled to run again.
